publicationStmt.idno: Source copy consulted: Oxford, Corpus Christi College, Oxford, MS 201

head.note: This folio marker does not represent a leaf boundary at this point, but it is included to make it possible to display the facsimile image from this passus file.

lg.l: ANdF.6.1: The ornamental capital is red with green flourishes which extend over half way up the page in the left margin. wanne y awakid was / y wondred were y were. These lines appear only in F.
Tyl Ã¾at y be-Ã¾owhte me / what Ã¾yng y dremede.

& y RobertF.6.3: The last four characters are virtually illegible because of bleed through and the translucency of the manuscript.F.6.3: The reading "y Robert" is unique to F. Bx reads yrobed. in russet / gan rome a-bowhte.F.6.3: F omits the following line: "Al a somer seson for to seke dowel."
& freynede fulF.6.4: The manuscript is almost completely illegible here. ofte / folk Ã¾at y mette.

If ony whyght wiste / where Dowel wereF.6.5: Alpha is responsible for were; beta witnesses (and A,C) read was. ostagid.F.6.5: ostagid, "lodged, dwelled, resided." This form is rare in Middle English. MED lists only one other occurrence.F.6.5: A rubricated "VI:" appears in the top right margin with red flourishes to indicate the passus number.
& what man he myghte be / of many a man y askede.
But Ã¾ere waswas [neuere] wyght as y went / Ã¾at me wysshe cowthe.
Where Ã¾at leede lengede / neyÃ¾ir lesse ne more.
Tyl it fel on a Fryday / with tweye Freris y mette.
&F.6.10: Alpha is responsible for &. weryn Maystrys of Ã¾e Menourys / & men weel y-lernede.F.6.10: F omits the following line from Bx: "I hailsed hem hendely as I hadde ylerned."
Â¶ I prayede hem pur charite / er y passede furthere.

If Ã¾ey knewe in ony cowrtF.6.12: Alpha is responsible for cowrt, a reading shared by Cr2,3. Beta witnesses read contree. / or in coostys Ã¾ereF.6.12: Alpha is responsible for Ã¾ere. Beta witnesses read as. Ã¾ey wentyn.

Where Ã¾at Dowel dwellyÃ¾ / y praye Èow Èee me wisse.F.6.13: Alpha lacks the following lines present in beta witnesses:
For Ã¾ei be men of Ã¾is moolde Ã¾at moost wide walken
And knowen contrees and courtes and many kynnes places
BoÃ¾e princes paleises and pouere mennes cotes
And dowel and do yuele where Ã¾ei dwelle boÃ¾e.
Â¶ Marye quod Ã¾o Menoures / a-mongys vs he dwellyÃ¾.
& euere haÃ¾ as y hope / & euere shal here-after.
Contra quod y / as a Clerk / & comsed to disputyn.F.6.16: F omits the following line from Bx: "And seide hem sooÃ¾ly Sepcies in die cadit Iustus."
For sevene tymes / as seyÃ¾ Ã¾e book / slyÈdiÃ¾ Ã¾e ryghtful.
& who Ã¾at synneÃ¾ in doynge / he doÃ¾ evele me Ã¾ynkiÃ¾.
& dowel & doevele / mowe not dwelle to-gydre.
Ergo he is nowht alwey / at hoom a-mong Èoure freres.
But he is ellis-wher / for to wisse Ã¾e peple.
Â¶ I shal seyÈe Ã¾e my sone / seyÈde Ã¾e toÃ¾e frere Ã¾anne.
How sevene sythis Ã¾e sad man / synneÃ¾ on Ã¾e day-tyÈde.
Be a propre resoun / y shal Ã¾e redyly shewe.
Lete brynge a man in a boot / a-myddis Ã¾e brode watur.
Ãe wynd / & Ã¾e watur / & the boot waggynge.
MakÃ¾ Ã¾e man many a tyme / to meve / & to stakere.
For stonde he neuere so stef / he stumbleÃ¾ & falleÃ¾.
& Èit is he saf & sownd / & so hym by-hoveÃ¾.
For but he ryse Ã¾e rathere / & rawhte to hym Ã¾e sterne.F.6.30: Alpha has sterne, a reading shared by HmC2. Other beta witnesses read steere. The same pattern of variation appears in A manuscripts.
Ãe wynd wolde / on Ã¾e watur / Ã¾e boot ouer-terve.
& Ã¾anne were his lyf loost / Ã¾orhÈ lacchesse of hym-selue.
Â¶ Ryght Ã¾us fareÃ¾ it quod Ã¾e Frere / by folk on Ã¾is grownde
Ãe watur y lykne to Ã¾is world / Ã¾at wanyeÃ¾ & wexiÃ¾.
& Ã¾e goodis on Ã¾is grownde / be lykned Ã¾e grete wawis.
& as Ã¾e wynd & Ã¾e wedir / walkyn a-bowte.
Ãe boot y lykne to oure bodijs / Ã¾at brotyl is of kyÈnde.
Ãat Ã¾orgh Ã¾e feend . & oure flesh / & Ã¾e false world also.
SynneÃ¾ Ã¾e sade man / ech day sevene syÈÃ¾ys.
Â¶ But dedly synne doÃ¾ he non / for Dowel hym helpiÃ¾.
& Ã¾at is Charite Ã¾e Champioun / cheef a-geyn synne.
For he strengÃ¾ man / to stonde / & steriÃ¾ mannys wille.
Ãat Ã¾eyhÈ Ã¾y body bowe / as Ã¾e boot in Ã¾e watir.
Euere ys Ã¾y sowle saf / but if Ã¾y-selue wille.
If Ã¾ou folwe Ã¾y fowle fleshÈ / & Ã¾e feend Ã¾ere-after.F.6.45: F alone among B manuscripts has this line, otherwise attested only by A manuscripts.
& doost dedly synne / Ã¾ou drenchist Ã¾anne Ã¾y sowle.

Â¶ But god wille Ã¾ou save Ã¾i sowleF.6.47: F's a-verse is unique, and the agreement of FHmR in reading sowle in place of the other beta manuscripts' reading sleuÃ¾e makes it difficult to determine the archetypal reading. It is likely to have read "God wole suffre wel Ã¾i sowle (or sleuÃ¾e)." / Ã¾yf[È]ifF.6.47: Though Norman Davis notes that isolated cases of scribal confusion of <Ã¾> and <È> occur occasionally elsewhere, the examples he cites are mainly from East Anglian texts. "A Scribal Problem in the Paston Letters," English and Germanic Studies 4 (1951-1952): 39. It is perhaps equally possible that this form represents the scribe's effort at the Worcester form yef or yif. Ã¾i-selue lyke.F.6.47: F revises this line radically. Bx reads "God wole suffre wel Ã¾i sleuÃ¾e if Ã¾iself likeÃ¾." Alpha must have had soule in place of sleuÃ¾e, and later F revised "suffre wel" to "Ã¾ou save" in an attempt to salvage some sense.
He Èaf Ã¾e / two ÈeresÈevis / to Èeeme wel Ã¾y-selue.
& Ã¾o ben wit / & frewil / to euery wyght a porcioun
To man & to foulis / to fyschis & to beestis
But man haÃ¾ moost Ã¾ereof / & moost he is to blame.
But he wyrche wel Ã¾er-with / as dowel hym techiÃ¾.
Â¶ Èee y have no kyÈnde knowynge quod y ï ¡ to conseyve Ã¾y wordis.
But if y may lyve & looke / y shal goo leerne bettre.
Â¶ I be-kenne Ã¾e Cryst quod he / Ã¾at on Ã¾e croys dyÈede.
& y seyde / Ã¾e same lord / save Ã¾e fram myschaunce.
& graunte Ã¾e grace on Ã¾is grownde / good ende to make.
/ [Â¶] & wente y wyÈde-where / walkynge by myn oone.
In a whilde wyÈldirnesse / by a wode-syÈde.
Ãanne blysse of Ã¾e bryddis / a-byÈde me made.F.6.60: Beta attests a different b-verse for this line: "brouÈte me aslepe." Alpha's reading corresponds to Cx.
& vndir a lyÈnde on a lawnde / lay y a stounde.

To lystne Ã¾e layÈes / Ã¾e Nytyngalis madenF.6.62: Bx reads for the b-verse: "Ã¾e louely foweles made," though R also omits the alliterating stave louely. That suggests that alpha had lost the alliterating word and that F had revised his defective exemplar. Cf. F's substitution of larkys for foweles at 5.358.
& Ã¾e merthe of here mowthis / made me on sleepe.
& Ã¾e mervylokest metelis / mette y Ã¾at stownde.
Ãat euere wyÈght / in Ã¾is world / as y wene dremede.
Â¶ Me Ã¾owhte oon com / & callyd me / be my ryght name These lines in F are transposed in relation to Bx.
A mychil man he was / mychil lyÈk my-selue.
Â¶ What art Ã¾ou quod y Ã¾o / Ã¾at Ã¾owhÈ my name knowist
Â¶ Thow wost wel quod he Ã¾o / & no whyÈt bettre.
I not neuere . who art Ã¾ou ï ¡ thowht y am he seyde.
& have sewid Ã¾e Ã¾is sevene Èeer / ne seyÈe Ã¾ou me no rathere.
Â¶ Art Ã¾ou Ã¾owht / quod y tho / canst Ã¾ou me telle.
Where Ã¾at dowel dwellyÃ¾ / Ã¾ou do me hymF.6.73: Alpha has hym. Beta witnesses read Ã¾at. to knowe.
Dowel quod he . & dobet / & dobest Ã¾e thrydde
Are Ã¾re faire felowis / & dwelle not feer o twynne.
For who is trewe of his tunge / & of hise two hondis.

& meeke in his herte / & myÈlde of his speche.F.6.77: This line uniquely appears in F in the B tradition. It appears in A, though it has correctly alliterating mouÃ¾ in place of herte. The line is omitted in C.
& trewe of his tayl-ende / & takÃ¾ but his owne. These lines in F are transposed in relation to Bx.
& Ã¾orghÈ Ã¾e labour of his hand / his lyfloode wynneÃ¾.
& nowht drunkelewhÈ ne deygnous / dowel hym folweÃ¾.
And dobet doÃ¾ ryght / but he doÃ¾ michil moore.
He is as lowhÈ as a lomb / & lowhly of speche.
& helpiÃ¾ alle men / & eseÃ¾ hem at neede.

Ãe baggys bownde with brygerdlisF.6.84: F's use of the form brygirdel (See MED s.v. brech-girdel) to mean bi-girdel, "money-belt," had already taken place in the manuscripts of the A text of Piers Plowman, but it does not occur in other B witnesses. / he haÃ¾ broke hem alle
Ãat Ã¾e Erl / sire Averouse / held for hise eyÈres.
& with Mammones mone / he haÃ¾ maad freenschepis.
& ys runne in-to religious / to rendre Ã¾e byble.
& precheÃ¾ Ã¾e peple / seynt Powlys woordis.

hi.hi: ibenter suffertis incipientes . cum ipsi scitis sapientes.

lg.l: He seyÃ¾ Èee sholde gladly suffre Ã¾e vnwyse / with Èow to lybbe.
& with glad wil don hem good / for god so Èow hoteÃ¾.
Â¶ But dobest beriÃ¾ a bisshopis croos / & is a-bove hem boÃ¾e.
It is hoked at Ã¾e ende / to halye men fram helle.
& in Ã¾at potente ys a pyÈk / to pytten doun Ã¾e wykkede.

Ãat wayten with wrong / sire dowel to teene.F.6.95: F lacks KD8.100-101 and re-orders several other lines. Alpha had already omitted KD8.106. The missing lines read:
And dowel and dobet amonges hem ordeyned
To crowne oon to be kyng to rulen hem boÃ¾e (=KD8.101).
But dobest bede for hem Ã¾ei to be Ã¾er for euere (=KD8.106).

Â¶ And Ã¾us dowel . & dobet . & dobest Ã¾e thrydde. In this and the next two paragraphs, a scribe subsequent to alpha augmented his text, probably from an A manuscript, but possibly, as Kane and Donaldson believe, a superior B manuscript.
Haue crownecrowne[d] oon to be kyng / & be here conseyl wircheF.6.97: F's b-verse reading is unique. Bx reads "to kepen hem alle."
& to rewle al Ã¾e rewhme / be reed of hem alle.F.6.98: F's b-verse reading is unique. Bx reads "by hire Ã¾re wittes."
& be non oÃ¾ir-wyse / but as Ã¾ey Ã¾re wille assente.
Â¶ For if Ã¾at dowel or dobet / dyden a-geyn dobest.
& weryn vn-buxum to don his byddyngge / & bown to do Ille.F.6.101: F alone among B manuscripts attests this line, which is found in A, but not in C.
Ãanne sholde Ã¾e kyng come / & comawnde hem to presoun.

& pitte hem Ã¾ere in penawnce / with-oute pite or grace.F.6.103: This line from the A version appears only in F among B manuscripts. Alpha omits the following line found in beta: "But dobest bede for hem Ã¾ei to be Ã¾er for euere."
Â¶ Ãanne Ã¾ankede y thowht Ã¾o / Ã¾at he so faire me tawhte.
& seyde / me savoureÃ¾ not Èyt wel / so me crist helpe. This b-verse and the following a-verse, found in Ax and Cx, are not attested in other B manuscripts.
For more kyÈnde knowynge / y coveyte of Èow to leerne.
Where Ã¾at dowel & dobet & dobest / doon on Ã¾is molde.
Trewly but . witt kan wisshe Ã¾e quod thowt / where Ã¾at Ã¾ey dwelle.
Ellis knowe y non Ã¾at can / Ã¾at now ys on lyve.
Â¶ Ão Ã¾owht & y / thre dayes we wentyn.
Disputynge on dowel / day after oÃ¾ir.
& er Ã¾at we weryn war / with witt gunne we meetyn
He was long & leene / & lyÈk to non oÃ¾ir.
Was no priÈde in his a-parayle / ne pouerte neythir.
But sad of his semblaund / & softe he was of chere.
I durste meve no matere / for to make hym Iangle.
But as y bad Ã¾owht Ã¾o / be meene be-twene.
To pytte furÃ¾ sum purpos / to prevyn hise wittis.
What was dowel fram dobet / & dobest fram hem bothe.
Â¶ Ãanne Ã¾owht in Ã¾at tyme / seyde Ã¾ese woordys.

Where dwellyÃ¾F.6.121: F uniquely has dwellyÃ¾, which then requires the omission of Bx's ben from the b-verse after dobest. Curiously, R also omits ben. dowel & dobet / & dobest in londe.F.6.121: F revises the next three lines, converting Thought's third person discourse into first person. Bx reads as follows:
Here is wil wolde wite if wit koude teche hym
And wheiÃ¾er he be man or no man Ã¾is man wolde aspie
And werchen as Ã¾ei Ã¾re wolde this is his entente.
Fayn wolde y wete witt / If Ã¾ou cowdist me telle.F.6.122: Bx reads here: "Here is wil wolde wite if wit koude teche hym."
WheyÃ¾ir he be man / or noon / y wolde fayn a-spyÈe.
& worchen as Èee[Ã¾]e[y] Ã¾re wolde / Ã¾is were myn entente.
Â¶ Sire dowel dwelliÃ¾ quod witt / nowht a day henne.
In a Castel Ã¾at Keende made / of foure manere of Ã¾yngis.
Of Erthe & eyÈr it ys maad / & medlyd to-gydres.
With wynd & with watur / wyttyrly en-Ioyned.
Syre Keende haÃ¾ closed Ã¾er-in / craftly withalle.
His lemmanF.6.130: The <a> in lemman is written, for no apparent reason, much larger than usual. Ã¾at he loveÃ¾ wel / she is lych hym-selue.
Anima she hatte / but Envie hyre hateÃ¾.
He is a prowd prikere of Fraunce / princeps huius mundi.
He wolde wynne hire a-weyÈ / with wyÈles if he myÈhte.F.6.133: The <y> is corrected from <u>.
& Ã¾at knoweth Kynde wel / & kepeÃ¾ hire Ã¾e bettre.
& doÃ¾ hire dwelle with dowelF.6.135: Alpha is responsible for the omission of sire before dowel. / Dewk of Ã¾at marches.F.6.135: F's Ã¾at is unique. R has Ã¾e, and beta manuscripts Ã¾ise.
& dobet ys hire Damysele / sire dowellis dowhtir.
She serueÃ¾ Ã¾at Lady leelly / boÃ¾e late & rathe.
& dobest ys above hem boÃ¾e / a Bisshopis peere.
& Ã¾at he byddis mote be doon / for he rewhliÃ¾ hem alle.
And Anima Ã¾at lady / ys lad by his leernynge.
Â¶ But Ã¾e Cunstable of Ã¾e Castel / Ã¾at kepeÃ¾ alle Ã¾e wacche.
Is a wyÈs knyght with-alle / sire Inwitt he hatte.
& haÃ¾ fyve faire sones / by his firste Lady.
sire Seewel & seywel / & sireF.6.144: Alpha's sire is matched by the C reading. Beta is like A in omitting it. herewel Ã¾e heende.
& sire wyrche wel with Ã¾yn hond / a whyht man of strengÃ¾e.

& sire Goweel on groundeF.6.146:F's reading is unique. Other witnesses have "Godefray Go-wel" in place of "Goweel on grounde." / a gret LordF.6.146: Alpha is responsible for singular "a gret Lord." Beta witnesses have "grete lordes." for-sothe.

Ãese sixeF.6.147: Though the archetypal reading was fyue, F has almost certainly supplied the correct reading. ben set / to save sown Ã¾ys Anima.F.6.147: Alpha's omission of beta's lady is matched by the C reading.
Tyl Kynde come or sende / to kepen hire hym-selue.
Â¶ What kenne Ã¾yng ys Kynde quod y ï ¡ canst Ã¾ou me telle.
Quod wit ï ¡ Kynde is a creatour / of alle kenne Ã¾yngys.
Fader & formere / of alle Ã¾ynge on erthe.
He is grete god / Ã¾at by-gynnynge hadde neuere.
& lord of lyf & of lyth / of blysse & of peyÈne.
Angelys & alle Ã¾ynge / ben at his wille.
But man ys moost hym lyÈkF.6.155: Alpha is responsible for the word order "moost hym lyÈk." Beta witnesses have "hym moost lik." / of makynge & of chafte.F.6.155: chafte, "shaft."

For Ã¾orghÈ Ã¾e word Ã¾at he spak / wentyn forÃ¾ beestys.F.6.156: The next three lines are unique to F, replacing the Latin tag "Dixit et facta sunt." Kane and Donaldson reject the first two as spurious and accept the substance of the third, though they emend it. Schmidt, Parallel-Text Edition, rejects all three.
& grene gres grew sone / on grownde al a-bowhte.
& trees weryn frawht with frut / fayre vpon erthe.
& al was maad Ã¾orgh his word / as his wille wolde.
/ [Â¶] But he made Adam a man / lykkest hym-selue.
& Eve was maad of Adam-is ryb / with-outyn ony meene.
& for he was nowht synguler / he seyÈde faciamus.
As who seyÈÃ¾ ï ¡ more mote here-to / Ã¾an my word oone.
For my myght mote helpe / forÃ¾ with my speche.
Ryght as a lord shold make a lettre / & only lakkede parchemyn
Or Ã¾eyÈ he cowhde wryte neuere so wel / & he lakkede a penne
Ãe Lettre for al his lordshepe / y leve sholde not be makyd
Ryght so it semeÃ¾ be god / as Ã¾e byble telleÃ¾
Ãere god seyde Ã¾is sawe / faciamus hominem ad ymaginem &c.F.6.169: The Latin tag is attested only in F at this point. Bx reads "dixit et facta sunt." F's reading mirrors Ax.
He wroghte Ã¾us with his word / & with his wit gan shewe
& in Ã¾is manere man was maad / Ã¾orhÈ Ã¾re persones oone.
With his word he wroghte man / & Èaf hym lyf after.F.6.172: F has extensively revised this line. Bx reads "WiÃ¾ his word and werkmanshipe and wiÃ¾ lif to laste."
& god gaf hym a goost / of Ã¾e godhed of hevene.
& of his grete grace / he grawntyd hym blysse.
Ãere is lyf Ã¾at euere shal laste / to alle his lynage after.
& Ã¾at Castel Ã¾at Kynde maade Caro itF.6.176: The rubricating scribe, whom we take to be the main text scribe, noticed that the <i> was not dotted and supplied it in red ink. hatte.
& is as mychel to mene / as man with a sowle.
& Ã¾at he wroughte it as[with] werk / & with hisF.6.178: Alpha is responsible for his, which is not in beta. word boÃ¾e.
Ãorgh myght of Ã¾e Mageste / Ã¾us was man y-maked.
Inwit & alle wittys / y-closed ben Ã¾ere-Inne.

For love of Ã¾at Lady anima / Ã¾at lyf is sprenklydF.6.181: Bx reads ynempned. F's reading is not easily accounted for by recourse to unconscious scribal substitution and perhaps reflects a conscious intention, but we find no appropriate sense for sprenklyd in this context.
Ouer al in mannys body / heF.6.182: he, "she." walweÃ¾ & wandreÃ¾.

But in Ã¾e herte . ys here hoom / & hereF.6.183: F rarely writes here for singular "her." However, since he probably did not recognize he in the preceding b-verse as "she," he probably took here in both cases to be plural "their," referring to "Inwit & alle wittys." moost reste.
Â¶ & Inwit ys in Ã¾e hevid / & to Ã¾e herte he lookeÃ¾.
What anima is leef or looÃ¾ / he ledeÃ¾ hire at his wylle.
For after Ã¾e grace of grete god / Inwit neest folwiÃ¾.
Mychil wo worÃ¾ Ã¾at wyght / Ã¾at Inwit may not rewle.
& Ã¾o been glotones & gloseris / Ã¾at god is in here wombe.
For swiche seruyn Sathan / & here sowlis he shal welde.
For Ã¾ey levyn synful lyf / here sowle ys lyÈk Ã¾e powke.
& Ã¾o Ã¾at lyvyn good lyf / lyk after goddis techyng
Seynt Iohan seyÃ¾F.6.193: F uniquely attributes the Latin quotation to Saint John. qui manet in caritate in deo manet & deus in eo.
Â¶ Allas ï ¡ Ã¾at drynk shal for-doon / Ã¾at god dere bowhte.
& doÃ¾ god for-saken hem / Ã¾at shoop hem after his lyknesse.F.6.195: F omits the following line from Bx: "Amen dico vobis nescio vos Et alibi Et dimisi eos secundum desideria eorum."

I fyÈnde Ã¾at holy chirche / sholde neuere faylyn foolys. F has heavily revised Bx, which reads as follows:
Fooles Ã¾at fauten Inwit I fynde Ã¾at holy chirche
Sholde fynden hem Ã¾at hem fauteth and faderlese children.
Ne knowe non defawhte / of faderlesF.6.197: An otiose curl appears above the <r>. chyldryn.
Ne wedewys Ã¾at have nout wherwith / to wynnyn here foode.
And madde men & maydenys / Ã¾at helpeles weryn.
For alle Ã¾ese lakkyn Inwit / & loore hem by-hoveÃ¾.
Â¶ But of Ã¾is matere y myghte / maken a long tale.
& fyÈnde fele wytnesse / of Ã¾e foure doctoures.
& Ã¾at y lyÈe nowht / seynt Luk beryÃ¾ witnesse.
Ãat boÃ¾e godfadir . & godmodire / Ã¾at seen here god-childryn.
In myssese & myscheef / & may hem wel a-mende.
Ãey shulle haue penaunce in purgatorye / but if Ã¾ey hem helpe.
For more longiÃ¾ a lytyl barn / er he Ã¾e lawe knowe.
Ãan nempne first his name / & he be neuere Ã¾e wysere.
Â¶ For Ã¾ere sholde no cristene creature / cryÈen at Ã¾yn Èate
&F.6.210: The ampersand is owed to alpha. Beta reads Ne. For a similar variation, see 11.8. faylen payn & potage / &F.6.210: The ampersand represents here an, "if." prelatys dyden here devir.
A Iew wolde not seen a Iew / goo Ianglynge for defawhte.
For alle Ã¾e mone on Ã¾e moolde / & he a-mende it myghte.
Allas Ã¾anne Ã¾at a cristene man / sholde so ben vn-kyÈnde.
Sytthyn Ã¾e Iewis Ã¾at we for-Iuggen / to ben Iudas felawe.
Ãat ech helpiÃ¾ oÃ¾ir of hemF.6.215: Alpha's a-verse differs from beta's "EyÃ¾er of hem helpeÃ¾ ooÃ¾er." F's ech is substituted for Bx's EyÃ¾er. / of good Ã¾at hem neediÃ¾.
/ [Â¶] Why wille[ny]lle we cristene of cristis good / ben also kyÈnde.

As Iewis Ã¾at ben for-lore menF.6.217: F's reading is unique, whether it is interpreted as "for lore-men," meaning "standing in place of teachers," or as we punctuated it here as "for-lore men," meaning "lost (or damned) men." Bx must have read "As Iewes Ã¾at ben oure loresmen shame to vs alle." / It is shame to vs alle.

Abrasion and cockling on the recto and either mildew damage or abrasion on this side make is very difficult to see. an komely[vn]komely cowple / by IesusF.6.292: Alpha is responsible for Iesus. To Èeve Èong[a] Èong Mayde / to an old baslard.F.6.293: Though it is possible that F's baslard reflects a slang usage unrecorded elsewhere, he probably meant to write bosard, "buzzard, old fool." See F7.285. Bx reads "an olde feble." What we have interpreted as <s> could equally well be an <f>.
